mainmatter.p: Given a topological space X, let \mathcal{O} ( X ) denote its class of opens.

As \mathcal{O} ( X ) is a frame, we can view this as a mapping \mathcal{O} : \mathbf{Top} \to \mathbf{Frm}, which we can then extend to a contravariant functor:
let f : X \to Y be a continuous map of topological spaces,
\mathcal{O} (f) should then be mapping from the frame \mathcal{O} ( Y ) to \mathcal{O} ( X ),
given some U \in \mathcal{O} ( Y ), \mathcal{O} (f)(U) := f^{-1}(U) which is in \mathcal{O} ( X ) precisely by the continuity of f.
The Stone adjunction is the one formed by the open set functor \mathcal{O} : \mathbf{Top} \to \mathbf{Frm} and the point functor \mathsf{Pt} : \mathbf{Frm} \to \mathbf{Top}.
Adapted by Ayberk Tosun from the handbook chapter of Abramsky and Jung.
